page.title: 03Yearly rhythm,Upper Otter:2
page.content: The sheep that took over the fields in the autumn were store lambs and ewes bought from Scotland,Hereford, Kent,etc.Popular breeds were Border Leicesters and Suffolks,with some handsome Jacobs here and there. Some of the autumn intake disappeared to market before Christmas but most were with us till Easter.As winter wore on and snow came,extra food was taken out to the flocks.From January on,tiny lambs appeared.By March the winter-fattened store lambs were being sold. Spring being late,the cows were not back in the fields till May,and tractors were not clattering up and down the lanes with silage till early June.Hay was made late,if at all,this year,but an Indian summer meant that second silage was successfully cut.
